title: About
text:
Nyssa Galatas is a student at the University of Texas at Dallas. I am pursuing a B.S. in Public Policy and a M.S. in Social Data and Analytics. I am also studying for a credential in Legal Research and a minor in Asian Studies.
I am a detail-oriented Public Policy student, focusing on policy effectiveness and the economic effects of government. I am interested in continuing to explore governmental law, code, and the use of textual data, spatial data, economic data, and web data in government.

title: Panel and Google Trends
text:
Qualtrics Panel
Hello! Access my survey through this link.


Google Trends
From the Google Trends website, you can see the difference in overall election searches, Trump, and Harris search terms.

Here, the 2020 election is the most popular, forming the maximum 100 value. Donald Trump’s popularity increases around the 2016 election and his presidency, then declines after he leaves office. Kamala Harris’s popularity is more minimal than either, with some increase after the launch of her presidential campaign.


Using the chart above, it is clear that in every state, Donald Trump takes up a larger percentage of searches than Kamala Harris.

Using ggtrends
With the ggtrends library, this data can also be summarized. Modeling total interest over time results in this graph:

From this, it is also visible that the popularity for elections peaked much higher in 2020 than in other years. The package allows for more manipulation of data, including the combination of topics seen above, than the Google Trends website alone allows.

title: Qualtrics Survey
text:
Hello! Access my survey through this link.
If you want it in a pdf form, click here.
The survey is structured in a linear format, with two skips available to avoid irrelevant questions for the user. The questionnaire is for distribution by a movie rental company to their customers. The questions have no clear order, but the most important information to the company appears to come first in the survey. Creating more skips for irrelevant questions and reordering the questions would be beneficial. This would make it such that if someone does not own a DVD player in question 3, they do not have to answer again in question 10.

title: Experience
section: Interning at National Conference for State Legislatures
text:
Interning at National Conference for State Legislatures
I worked at NCSL for six months, from the beginning of 2024 through the summer. Here are some of the many tasks I performed while with them:

Publishing an Article

While working at NCSL, I was lucky enough to help out with many projects and tasks. One of those was the opportunity to publish a summary article of a brief by Andrew Smalley, who I interned under. This covers some of the recent efforts done by states to make more efficient workforce systems.


Tracking Postsecondary Legislation
My primary task working at NCSL was to track and categorize state legislation for higher education and workforce efforts. I tracked around 2000 pieces of legislation in topic areas ranging from dual enrollment to financial aid. Look through the legislation below:



Look through legislation here!




Student Loan Database




Look through Student Loan Legislation here!


One other database I tracked legislation for as an intern was our Student Loan Bill Tracking Database. This takes the legislation passed and categorizes it further in a Power BI database to break down forgiveness, licensure, oversight, and tax bills into their own groupings. Check it out!

Working as a Student Tour and Admission Representative
I currently work as a tour guide for the University of Texas at Dallas. There, I perform administrative tasks like calls, mailing of promotional items, and answering visitor questions. I also help coordinate and work our Scholars’ Day events, which have around over 1000 guests in total!

title: Quanteda and Textual Analysis
text:
Analysis of Biden-Xi Summit Speeches
From the built in data in Quanteda, we can see popular accounts that tweeted about the summit.



Analysis of Presidential Speeches
Using the wordcloud analysis, the most common words can be highlighted.

This can also be broken out by president, with Bush, Obama, and Trump’s most frequent words seen below.

These words can then be graphed by their frequency, as seen for the previous four administrations below.

Using an x-ray plot, the frequency of specific terms can be seen across different administrations below.



Wordfish
Wordfish aligns words dimensionally based on relationships between them. It’s used to arrange words ideologically, especially in politics. It’s based on the frequency of the words used and their frequency in relation to other words and assumes a single-dimension to words and that users with such beliefs use the words more frequently. It generates a roughly curved graph that looks like a fishtail, hence the name.

title: Youtube API
text:
Data from Webscraping
You can see some of the output from the code here:

Some charts of the analysis of the channel are below:


There are two broad conclusions from the data. Firstly, as expected, videos with more views get more likes and comments. Additionally, the majority of videos have low videos, likes, and comment values, with only a few having high numbers of all. This is also consistent with the expected idea that most videos are not viral.
Because of the restrictions on queries, I could not use comment data thoroughly. However, if the comment data were compiled into a corpus for analysis, it could be used for textual analysis.

title: Webscraping
text:
Resources from Webscraping
Access the csv format of the Texas 2022 Elections data I scraped through this link.
If you want to see some of the government documents I scraped, click any of the links below:
Senate Resolution 115 of the 118th Session
Senate Resolution 805 of the 118th Session
Senate Resolution 890 of the 118th Session
Senate Record for September 15th, 2024


Results of Webscraping
While the resources already in a csv format are usable to some extent, the pdf files are not well formatted for analysis. If the search were filtered for a specific type of government document, such as resolutions, it is possible that a consistent format could be used to extract text from the data. However, in its current format, the pdf file type is limiting to the use for textual analysis.
